vi_translation: The house in Berlin was located on a quiet street, lined with a series of large houses like yours, and every time you looked at them, you felt great because they were almost identical but not exactly the same as your house, and because there were other boys living in them, boys you played with (if they were friends) or avoided (if they often caused trouble for you). The new house stood alone on an open plot of land, isolated and with no other houses in sight, meaning there were no families living nearby and no boys to play with, whether they were friends or bullies.
tr_translation: The house in Berlin was on a quiet street, and there were a few other large houses like theirs on the same row. It was pleasant to look at them; because although not exactly, they were almost like their own house. In those houses lived other children, with whom they played together if they were friends, or stayed away from if they were troublemakers. The new house stood alone in the middle of an empty space. There were no other houses in sight. This meant there would be no other families, friends, troublemakers, or other children to play with.
es_translation: The house in Berlin was on a quiet street where there were other very large houses as well, and he liked to look at them because they were almost the same as his, although not identical, and in them lived other children with whom Bruno played (if they were friends) or whom he avoided (if they were rivals). The new one, on the other hand, was isolated, in an empty and desolate place, and there were no other houses nearby, which meant there would be no other families in the neighborhood nor other children to play with, neither friends nor rivals.

vi_translation: You went upstairs and slowly turned around in a full circle, hoping to find a small door or a discreet wall nook where you could finally do some real exploration, but there was no such place. On your floor, there were only four doors, two on each side, facing each other. One door to your own room, one door to Gretel's room, one door to your parents' room, and one door to the bathroom.
tr_translation: He went upstairs and slowly turned, drawing a circle. He hoped to find a small door or hole sufficient for proper investigation; but there was none. On this floor, there were only four doors; two on each side, opposite each other. One door led to his own room, one to Gretel's room, one to the parents' room, and one to the bathroom.
es_translation: He went up to the floor above and turned slowly, making a full circle, hoping to discover a small door or a closet that he could explore later, but there was nothing. On that floor, there were only four doors, two on each side of the hallway, facing each other. One led to his bedroom, another to Gretel's bedroom, another to Mother and Father's bedroom, and another to the bathroom.

tr_translation: He walked slowly towards the window; he hoped to see Berlin, his home, and the streets around his house, the people sitting at tables, telling funny stories while drinking their frothy drinks. He proceeded slowly; because he did not want to be disappointed. But this was just a small child's room, and it didn't take long for him to reach the window. He pressed his face against the glass and saw what was outside. This time, when his eyes opened wide and his mouth formed an O shape, his arms did not extend but stayed by his side. Because something had caused him to feel a cold shiver and insecurity.
es_translation: He approached little by little, hoping to catch sight of Berlin and his house and the surrounding streets and the tables where the neighbors sat to drink their frothy beverages and tell each other very funny stories. He advanced slowly because he didn't want to be disappointed. But since that was a child's bedroom, he didn't have to walk too far to reach the window. He pressed his face against the glass and saw what was outside, and this time, although his eyes opened wide and his lips formed an O, his hands remained glued to his sides because something made him feel a very intense cold and fear.

vi_translation: At first, that scene was also very interesting. There was a garden right below Bruno's room window. It was quite spacious, full of various flowers planted in neat beds as if someone had taken great care of them, someone who knew that planting flowers in a place like this meant they had done something beautiful, like placing a tiny candle in the corner of a grand castle on a desolate hill in the dark winter night.
tr_translation: It started beautifully: there was a garden right under Bruno's window. It was quite spacious and full of flowers. They were neatly arranged in rows, as if organized by someone who knew how to grow flowers. They had tried to do something good; like placing a small candlelight in the corner of a giant castle on a dark winter night, in a misty, vast land. After passing the flowers, there was a very pleasant, stone-paved area.
es_translation: At first glance, it wasn't so bad. Right below Bruno's window, there was a fairly large garden filled with flowers in neat and orderly flowerbeds. They seemed very well cared for by someone who had understood that planting flowers in a place like that was a good idea, just as it would have been, on a dark winter night, to light a small candle in the corner of a gloomy castle situated in the middle of a misty moor.

en: There wasnâ€™t any grass after the fence; in fact there was no greenery anywhere to be seen in the distance. Instead the ground was made of a sand-like substance, and as far as she could make out there was nothing but low huts and large square buildings dotted around and one or two smoke stacks in the distance. She opened her mouth to say something, but when she did she realized that she couldnâ€™t find any words to express her surprise, and so she did the only sensible thing she could think of and closed it again.

vi_translation: On the other side of the fence, there wasn't a single blade of grass; in fact, from this distance, no green could be seen at all. Instead, the ground looked like it was made of a material similar to sand, and from what her eyes could make out, there was nothing more than low barracks and a few large square buildings scattered around, with one or two smoke stacks in the distance. She intended to say something, but as soon as she opened her mouth, she realized she couldn't find the words to express her amazement, so she did the only sensible thing she could think of and closed her mouth again.
tr_translation: There was no grass beyond the wire fence; in fact, there was no greenery as far as the eye could see. Instead, the ground was made of a substance similar to sand. All he could see were a few clusters of smoke that seemed to be scattered among the low barracks and square buildings in the distance. He opened his mouth to say something, but realized there was no word to express his astonishment; then he did the only logical thing that came to mind and closed his mouth again.
es_translation: Behind the barbed wire, no grass grew; in fact, in the distance, no type of vegetation could be seen. The ground seemed sandy, and Gretel only saw small huts and large square buildings, separated from each other, and one or two columns of smoke in the distance. She opened her mouth to say something, but couldn't find the words to express her surprise, so she did the only sensible thing she could think of: she closed it again.

vi_translation: He walked slowly, but once he left the room, he quickly headed towards the stairs and then ran down the steps at a terrifying speed, suddenly feeling that if he didn't run out of the house immediately, he would faint. From a distance, he could see the gate leading to the road that would take him to the train station to go home, but the idea of rushing out there, the idea of escaping only to be alone with no one by his side, made him even sadder than the thought of staying here.

He could see the gate opening to the main road in the distance, and that road led to the train station that would take them home. But the idea of going there, the idea of escaping and being all alone, seemed even more unpleasant to him than the idea of staying here.

es_translation: "Well, I'm afraid that won't be possible for the moment," said Father. "I'm afraid the Fury hasn't planned to relieve me of my post yet." "On the other hand, Mother thinks this would be a good time for you three to go back home and settle there, and thinking about it... â€”He paused briefly and looked out the window to his left, through which the field on the other side of the fence could be seenâ€”. "Thinking about it, maybe she's right." "Maybe this isn't a suitable place to raise two children."
